title: ViewSonic VX2758A-2K-PRO-3 review: 240Hz without breaking the bank - The Times of India
text:
The ViewSonic VX2758A-2K-PRO-3 sits in that sweet spot where ambitious specs meet reasonable pricing. At around ₹21,000, it promises 27-inch 2K gaming at 240Hz, numbers that would have cost twice as much just a couple of years ago. But beyond the impressive spec sheet lies a monitor that's refreshingly honest about what it delivers. Function over form The VX2758A-2K-PRO-3 won't win any design awards, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. ViewSonic has gone for a no-nonsense approach with matte black plastic construction and slim bezels that fade into the background. There's no RGB lighting or aggressive gaming aesthetics here, just a monitor that does its job without demanding attention. The build quality feels solid enough for the price point. The metal base provides decent stability, though you'll notice some wobble if you're an enthusiastic desk-thumper. The chassis itself doesn't creak or flex, which is more than you can say for some budget displays. Here's where reality sets in: the included stand only tilts. No height adjustment, no swivel, no rotation. If you're not sitting at the perfect height or prefer portrait orientation for coding, you'll need to budget extra for a VESA arm. It's a practical limitation that keeps costs down, but one that might catch some buyers off guard. The connectivity is refreshingly straightforward, two HDMI 2.1 ports and one DisplayPort 1.4. No USB hub, no built-in speakers, no unnecessary bells and whistles. For most gaming setups involving a PC and console, this covers the basics without cable clutter. Speed meets reality The 27-inch SuperClear IPS panel is where this monitor starts to shine. The 2560×1440 resolution hits the sweet spot for modern gaming, sharp enough to appreciate detail without demanding flagship GPU horsepower. Colors pop with that characteristic IPS vibrancy, and viewing angles remain consistent even when you're gaming from the couch. The 240Hz refresh rate is the star of the show, though with some caveats. When your hardware can push those frame rates, the difference from 144Hz is noticeable, not revolutionary, but definitely smoother. Fast-paced shooters like Valorant and CS2 feel more responsive, with reduced motion blur during quick camera movements. AMD FreeSync Premium and G-Sync compatibility work as advertised, eliminating screen tearing across a wide refresh range. The 1ms MPRT response time keeps ghosting to a minimum, though enabling this mode dims the display noticeably and disables HDR. Speaking of HDR, let's manage expectations. With a peak brightness of around 300 nits, HDR10 support feels more like a checkbox feature than a genuine enhancement. Colors become oversaturated rather than truly dynamic, and bright scenes lose their punch. You're better off sticking to SDR for consistent image quality. Color accuracy is decent out of the box but not exceptional. Professional work requiring precise colors will need calibration, though casual content creation and gaming look perfectly fine. The sRGB mode covers the full gamut but runs dimmer than ideal for daytime use. Doing double duty While marketed primarily for gaming, the VX2758A-2K-PRO-3 handles other tasks reasonably well. Movie watching benefits from the wide viewing angles and solid contrast, though the modest brightness means HDR content won't deliver the intended impact. The anti-glare coating helps in bright rooms but introduces a subtle grainy texture that becomes noticeable with pure white backgrounds. For productivity work, the 27-inch 2K resolution provides ample screen real estate. Text remains sharp, and color-sensitive tasks like photo editing are manageable with some tweaking. The lack of height adjustment becomes more apparent during long work sessions, where ergonomics matter more than in gaming scenarios. The blue light filter and flicker-free technology genuinely help during extended use. Eye strain feels reduced compared to cheaper panels, making this monitor viable for both work and play without constant mode switching. Content consumption falls somewhere in the middle. Streaming services look crisp and colorful, though the limited brightness means darker scenes can feel washed out in bright rooms. The wide color gamut helps animated content and games pop, but live-action HDR material doesn't quite reach its potential. The reality check The ViewSonic VX2758A-2K-PRO-3 succeeds by being honest about its priorities. It's a gaming monitor first, with other uses being pleasant bonuses rather than primary strengths. The 240Hz performance is genuine and smooth when your hardware can deliver, making competitive gaming feel notably more responsive. The compromises are clear but reasonable. The basic stand limits positioning options, HDR performance underwhelms, and color accuracy requires tweaking for professional work. But these aren't deal-breakers, they're conscious trade-offs that keep the price accessible. For competitive gamers upgrading from 60Hz or 1080p displays, the improvement will feel transformative. The combination of higher resolution and refresh rate creates a notably more immersive experience. Casual users will appreciate the crisp visuals and smooth motion, even if they never approach 240fps. This monitor delivers exactly what it promises, high refresh rate 2K gaming at for Rs 20,000. The limitations are present but predictable, making it an easy recommendation for anyone prioritising performance over premium features.
